awd_titl_txt: Laboratory and Modeling Studies of the Growth Efficiency of Vapor Grown Ice
awd_abstract_narration:
Cirrus clouds exist in extremely cold conditions where there is very little moisture.  The pathways for the growth of ice particles that make up cirrus and other cold clouds is complex, and there are gaps in the understanding of how these crystals increase in size and mass.  This award will focus on vapor growth, which is the process in which water vapor is deposited onto ice crystals.  The research team runs a very specialized cloud chamber that allows for the testing of the growth of individual crystals at extremely cold temperatures.  The main benefit of this research is to provide a check on numerical models that simulate cold clouds and to provide input parameters to those models.  This will have an impact on societally-relevant weather forecasts and climate projections.  The project will also help to train the next generation of scientists and provide interesting outreach opportunities to increase public science literacy.

The research team will continue their studies into the growth of ice crystals in atmospheric cold clouds.  The focus of the work is on addressing a critical gap in the understanding of the deposition coefficient at very cold temperatures.  The work will make use of a levitation diffusion chamber and vertical flow levitation chamber to grow ice crystals in different conditions.  The lab data will be used synergistically with existing and new theoretical models to derive input parameters for cloud models.  The specific objectives of the work are to determine:  1) Whether it is a robust result that the deposition coefficients cover a larger range for homogeneously frozen drops than heterogeneously frozen drops, 2) Whether characteristic supersaturations extracted from the levitation diffusion chamber follow the values estimated from prior measurements at temperatures below -40C, 3) If growth transitions are unique to homogeneously frozen drops and whether a model of the process can be constructed, and 4) Whether a power law parameterization of kinetics-diffusion limited growth can be constructed based on fits to laboratory data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the growth of ice particles is critical for predicting the evolution of atmospheric cold clouds. Ice particles are important producers of precipitation of all types and are important for predicting the radiative budget of the planet. Cirrus clouds that reside in the upper part of Earth's atmosphere have temperatures that range between -35 and -70C, and these clouds are composed entirely of ice. The computer models used to forecast these clouds and ice precipitation, and those that simulate the climate require methods to predict the growth of ice. Unfortunately, few measurements have been made of ice crystal growth at temperatures below -40C. This lack of data hampers our efforts to understand the growth of ice at low temperatures, and without data we cannot critique and improve our models for ice growth.

 

Research conducted under this grant produced new data on the growth of ice crystals ranging from -40C to -65C and over a wide range of moisture conditions. We measured the growth rates of small crystals similar to those found in cirrus clouds. Our results showed that when the moisture content is low the predicted growth is often substantially lower than that calculated by current theories. New theories developed under this and prior funding were used to explain the results, and to develop better methods to calculate the growth of ice in forecast models. When the moisture content is high, our measurements show that the growth rate can be substantially larger what is predicted by current theories. We hypothesize that the small crystals grown in our chamber develop branching arms and hollowed regions that enhance the growth rate, and theoretical models were developed to explain the growth. In order to examine larger, precipitation-sized crystals, we used a fiberglass substrate to support the growing ice. Measuring the growth rates of these larger crystals allowed us to estimate parameters needed to predict the evolution of the crystal dimensions at low temperatures. The results from our experiments were used in new ice crystal growth calculations for cloud forecasting models. Computer simulations using the new ice growth method have helped to shed light on the evolution of both cirrus clouds and cold, snow producing stratus clouds.These models have been released in the 2019 version of the Weather Research and Forecasting model.
